race.name: Big Sugar
race.tagline: Southern hospitality meets gravel brutality in the Ozark Mountains.

vitals.county: Benton County / McDonald County (crosses into Missouri)

climate.description: Late October brings crisp mornings, mild afternoons, and peak fall colors

terrain.primary: Ozark Mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs
terrain.surface: Variable gravel quality—smooth to chunky, with some technical sections

history.origin_story: Created as part of Life Time's Grand Prix series, leveraging Bentonville's growing reputation as a cycling destination. Named for the beautiful Sugar Creek that runs through the course.
notable_moments: Featured on Life Time Grand Prix circuit
Known for stunning fall colors and challenging course
history.reputation: The fall classic. Where the Grand Prix battles play out in the Ozark Mountains.

course_description.character: Relentless punchy climbing with technical descents. The Ozarks don't have long climbs—they have endless short ones.

suffering_zones.label: Welcome to the Ozarks
suffering_zones.desc: The punchy climbs start adding up. You realize there's no flat.

suffering_zones.label: War Eagle Territory
suffering_zones.desc: Deep in the course. The climbing feels personal.

suffering_zones.label: Final Push
suffering_zones.desc: Legs are shattered but the Ozarks aren't done with you yet.

course_description.signature_challenge: The accumulated vertical. 9,500 feet sounds manageable until you realize it comes in 50+ individual climbs. Death by a thousand punches.

prestige.explanation: A Life Time Grand Prix race with serious pro attendance. Not quite Unbound's fame, but finishing Big Sugar carries weight. The course difficulty earns respect.

length.explanation: 100 miles with nearly 10,000 feet of climbing in the punchy Ozarks. This isn't a cruiser—expect 6-10 hours depending on fitness.

technicality.explanation: More technical than Midwest gravel. Steep descents, varied surface quality, and fatigue make this a bike-handling challenge. Skills matter here.

elevation.explanation: 9,500 feet of gain across 100 miles, almost all in short punchy climbs. There's no recovering on 'flat' sections because there aren't any.

climate.explanation: Late October in the Ozarks is generally pleasant. Mornings are cool, afternoons comfortable. The main wildcard is rain turning the course muddy.

altitude.explanation: Ozark elevations top out around 2,000 feet. Altitude is a non-factor. Train anywhere.

adventure.explanation: Peak fall colors in the Ozarks are spectacular. Bentonville is a world-class cycling town. The combination of racing and destination makes this special.

biased_opinion.summary: Big Sugar takes everything great about fall gravel—colors, weather, community—and combines it with a legitimately hard course. The Ozarks' endless punchy terrain creates a unique challenge. Add Bentonville's cycling culture and you've got a complete experience.
strengths: The destination: Bentonville is cycling paradise. Trails, restaurants, coffee, culture.
The scenery: Peak fall colors make suffering beautiful.
The competition: Grand Prix field brings energy and racing.
weaknesses: The punchy terrain: If you're a diesel, this course will frustrate you.
Travel: Bentonville is accessible but not a major hub. Northwest Arkansas (XNA) is the airport.
October weather: Generally great, but rain creates mud fest potential.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want a fall gravel destination with a legitimately hard course and world-class town, Big Sugar delivers. Just bring your climbing legs.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: The 'punchy' climbing style of the Ozarks rewards a specific rider type. If you're all about steady-state power and long climbs, this course will shred you with its repeated accelerations.
consequences: Training should include VO2max work and repeated short efforts—not just tempo.
Bentonville is awesome but hotels book up. Plan early.
The technical descents when tired create real crash risk. Stay focused late in the race.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This isn't a race you can diesel through. The constant on/off nature of Ozark terrain requires specific fitness. A 12-week plan with punchy interval focus is essential.

final_verdict.one_liner: Fall gravel perfection—stunning scenery, world-class town, legitimately hard course.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you love punchy terrain and want a complete cycling destination experience. Maybe not if you're strictly a flat-course diesel.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want fall gravel without the punchy terrain: Gravel Worlds (Nebraska, flatter). If you want Ozarks without the distance: shorter Big Sugar distances.

logistics.airport: Northwest Arkansas (XNA) - 20 minutes to Bentonville. Tulsa (TUL) - 2 hours.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Book 3+ months early. Bentonville hotels are nice but limited. Consider Rogers or surrounding areas.
logistics.food: Bentonville food scene is excellent. Plan a nice dinner.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday at event expo. Great vendors, good energy.
logistics.parking: Downtown start requires early arrival or shuttle from remote lots.
